Am I missing something here: My solution(intuition-wise) to the Monty Hall problem is as follows: Take 2 cases and the strategy is to just switch. Case 1: You've chosen the correct door. Probability currently is 1/3. Now you switch: the probability of winning now is 0. -> 0 Case 2: You've chosen the wrong door. Probability currently is 2/3. Now you switch: the probability of winning now is 1.  -> 2/3 Probability of winning with the switching strategy is 2/3

The intuition and a proof for the monty hall problem is really simple...  if you're doing the switching strategy, then you will win if and only if you initially choose a non-prize door. Thus, if you're doing the switching strategy,  prob(winning) = prob(initially picking a non-prize door) =2/3.  See a reply to this for a more formal proof of this.

C= the event that my initial guess is correct. S= the event where I use the switching strategy. W= the event where I win my car.   Now  if S is true (not C)=>W     because the host has to pick the only other goat door, leaving the car door as the other option that I switch to.  Therefore prob ((W) given (notC) =1.  Similarly, given S,  (W==> (not C) ).  Because if i initially chose the winning door(C), switching would make me lose. So if I won,  must have initially had a goat door.   Thus prob((not C ) given W ) =1.  Now still assuming I'm doing the switching strategy, by Bayes theorem:  Prob((W) given (not C)) = Prob((not C) given W)*Prob(W)/Prob(not C)  Subbing in 1 for the conditional probabilities we have  1= 1*Prob(W)/Prob(not C) ==> prob(notC)= Prob(W).   But we know prob (notC)= 2/3... Therefore, drum roll, if I do the switching strategy my probability of winning is 2/3.   But it's an axiomatic Bayesian assumption to say that if a<==>b then prob(a)= prob(b),  so it should suffice to show that when doing the switching strategy: (initially picking a goat door)<==>(winning)...  To me this proof is really obvious and I can't believe so many people struggle with this.
